title: Parents pay kids $30 a week in allowance. What lessons are they learning?
text:
CLOSE

Parents give kids about $30 in allowance and expect chores to be done in return. (Photo: Getty Images)

How much is the average American kid's allowance? Enough to snag the latest iPhone after a few months of socking away dollars and dimes.

Parents typically give their kids $30 a week, according to a new survey from the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants that was conducted by the Harris Poll.

Fifty-two percent of Americans say chores should be required: The kids should have to take out the trash, wash the dishes or fulfill other household tasks to earn their spending money.

Eighty percent of mothers and fathers who give their children an allowance say they expect them to spend at least an hour a week on chores.

Those who have to work for their allowance tend to reap more, earning $6.11 an hour on average, a 38% jump from the typical $4.43 kids saw in 2016.

However much they earn, kids aren’t keen on saving, spending 45% of their allowance on hanging out with buddies and 37% on digital devices or downloads.

All that splurging shows that kids may be missing a key lesson receiving an allowance should teach – how to handle money.

“Simply handing money over to a child without guidance is a missed opportunity," Gregory Anton, chair of the AICPA’s National CPA Financial Literacy Commission, said in a statement announcing the survey's results. “By making an allowance a teachable moment, parents will help instill money management skills in their child at a young age that will help prepare them for the important financial decisions they’ll have to make when they’re older."

Though more than nine in 10 parents say it is very important for their children to know how to make smart decisions about their money, 32% give their kids financial lessons once a month or less, and 7% of them have never given their children tips about money.

Here are a few goals the commission says parents should keep in mind:

CLOSE You would think people with $1 million would be set for life. Most would disagree. USA TODAY

Begin when the kids are young

“Give them small jobs to earn their own money to pay for toys or other wants and help them to see their efforts grow with a chart on the fridge, showing the progress they are making towards their goal," Jaleigh White, a certified public accountant and member of the commission, said in the statement.

Tell kids money comes with strings

Whether their weekly payout is linked to household tasks or they're offered ways to boost their allowance, “make sure your children understand why they are getting it, how they can earn it and how they can lose it," said CPA and commission member Matthew Rosenberg.

Teach kids to do the math

If they want to go to a concert or buy a device, show your child how to figure how much they need to regularly save to make that purchase. Kids can be encouraged to divide their money between immediate wants, such as going to a movie with friends, and longer-term goals, such as saving for college. Consider mimicking the dollar match many employers offer employees who contribute to their 401(k) savings plan, similarly matching whatever your child manages to save.
